subject: how to use Unicode
msgSnippet: I installed the fonts in the fonts file and created a an example file with both Latin1 and UTF8 encoding, and low and behold, the text appeared perfectly in my
messageBody:
I installed the fonts in the fonts file and created a an example file
with both Latin1 and UTF8 encoding, and low and behold, the text
appeared perfectly in my browser! The only problem occurred when I
didn't specify the Kinsley font for the text in Unicode, and the
characters did not appear correctly. Likewise, when I opened the test
page from the files section of this mailing list on by browser, the
first test appeared correctly, but the second appeared as a mix of Asian
and QuickScript (QS) characters. If I want to mix Traditional
Orthography (TO) and QS, I don't want to specify the Kingsley code,
because then the text in TO will appear wrong.

Also, how exactly does one use the Unicode fonts? Though they appear
correct in an HTML browser, one can't type it in directly in any program
that I know of. I wish I could type QS Unicode in a text editor like VIM
instead of having to used an RTF editor and then paste it into the
document I need.

At any rate, I can write documents in HTML, format them with a print CSS
stylesheet, and then convert them to PDF, which anyone can read, and
which allows me to have a print copy in front of me. I prefer reading a
piece of paper instead of a screen. So thanks amd64 for the hints, and
thank you all who created the QS fonts.

Paul
